name: Hae Cho (Prawn Rolls)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Peranakan/Teochew home cooks.
description: A classic Teochew/Peranakan festive dish in Singapore, featuring minced prawn and pork seasoned with five spice, wrapped in beancurd skin and deep-fried until crisp. Served with sweet sauce and chili.

name: Fish Maw Soup (Yu Piu Tang)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Chinese home cooks.
description: A classic Chinese banquet and hawker soup in Singapore, featuring fish maw, crab meat, prawns, and mushrooms in a rich, savory broth. Served with black vinegar and white pepper, it's a festive favorite.

name: Singapore Chilli Crab
source: https://www.noobcook.com/chilli-crab/
description: Iconic Singaporean dish of mud crab stir-fried in a sweet, spicy, and tangy tomato-chili sauce.

name: Black Pepper Crab
source: https://www.noobcook.com/black-pepper-crab/
description: Mud crab stir-fried in a bold, peppery sauce with butter, garlic, and spring onions.

name: Sambal Stingray
source: https://www.seriouseats.com/sambal-stingray-recipe
description: Grilled stingray slathered with spicy sambal, served on banana leaf.

name: Cereal Prawns
source: https://www.noobcook.com/cereal-prawns/
description: Crispy prawns coated in buttery cereal crumbs, curry leaves, and chili padi.

name: Assam Fish
source: https://www.seriouseats.com/assam-fish-recipe
description: A spicy and sour fish curry made with tamarind, belacan, and a variety of fresh vegetables.

name: Steamed Teochew Fish
source: https://www.seriouseats.com/steamed-teochew-fish-recipe
description: A delicate steamed fish dish with a fragrant sauce made from fermented bean curd, garlic, and ginger.

name: Salted Egg Yolk Prawns
source: https://www.seriouseats.com/salted-egg-yolk-prawns-recipe
description: Prawns coated in a rich, creamy salted egg yolk sauce, served with steamed rice.

name: Drunken Prawns
source: https://www.seriouseats.com/drunken-prawns-recipe
description: Prawns cooked in a sweet, spicy, and aromatic sauce, infused with rice wine and spices.

name: Steamed Bamboo Clam with Garlic Vermicelli
source: https://www.noobcook.com/steamed-bamboo-clam/
description: Fresh bamboo clams steamed with garlic, vermicelli, and soy sauce. A seafood delicacy often found at zi char and seafood restaurants.

name: Steamed Cockles with Garlic and Chili Sauce
source: https://www.noobcook.com/steamed-cockles/
description: Fresh blood cockles (see hum) steamed and served with a spicy garlic-chili dipping sauce. A hawker and seafood favorite.

name: Cantonese Steamed Fish
source: https://www.noobcook.com/steamed-fish/
description: A classic Cantonese-style steamed whole fish with soy sauce, ginger, and spring onions. Delicate, aromatic, and a staple at Chinese banquets.

name: Nyonya Steamed Fish
source: https://www.noobcook.com/nyonya-steamed-fish/
description: A Peranakan-style steamed fish with lemongrass, lime, chili, and aromatic herbs. Fragrant, tangy, and spicy.

name: Salted Egg Yolk Crab
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore seafood restaurants.
description: A modern zi char and seafood favorite: crab stir-fried in a rich, creamy salted egg yolk sauce with curry leaves and chili. Iconic at Singapore seafood restaurants.

name: Ikan Bakar (Grilled Spiced Fish)
source: Adapted from Singapore/Malaysia hawker and home cook recipes.
description: A Malay and Indonesian favorite: whole fish marinated in a spicy sambal, grilled over charcoal or pan, often wrapped in banana leaves for extra aroma. Served with lime and sambal belacan.

name: Soy Sauce Chicken (Si Yau Kai)
source: Adapted from The Food Canon, Chew Kee, and Hawker Chan recipes.
description: A beloved Cantonese dish popular in Singapore, featuring whole chicken gently poached in a fragrant soy sauce-based broth. Famous at hawker stalls like Hawker Chan and Chew Kee, this dish is prized for its tender, juicy meat and glossy, savory skin.

name: Paper-Wrapped Chicken (纸包鸡)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Cantonese home cooks.
description: A Cantonese-origin dish popular in Singapore, featuring marinated chicken pieces wrapped in parchment and deep-fried or baked. The result is juicy, aromatic chicken infused with soy, sesame oil, and Chinese wine.

name: Singapore Hokkien Mee
source: https://rasamalaysia.com/singapore-hokkien-mee-recipe/
description: A classic Singapore hawker dish of stir-fried yellow noodles and rice vermicelli, prawns, squid, and pork belly, braised in a rich homemade prawn stock. Served with sambal and lime for a true hawker experience.

name: Char Kway Teow
source: https://www.recipetineats.com/char-kway-teow/
description: A legendary Singaporean and Malaysian hawker dish of stir-fried flat rice noodles with prawns, Chinese sausage, fish cake, egg, bean sprouts, and garlic chives, all tossed in a savory-sweet sauce and cooked over high heat for signature wok hei.

name: Singapore Carrot Cake (Chai Tow Kway)
source: Adapted from Serious Eats, Rasa Malaysia, and NLB Singapore Infopedia.
description: A beloved Singapore hawker dish of pan-fried radish cake cubes, stir-fried with eggs, garlic, preserved radish, and scallions. Available in white (savory) or black (with sweet soy sauce) versions.

name: Oyster Omelette (Orh Luak)
source: Adapted from The Burning Kitchen, What To Cook Today, and Nomadette.
description: A classic Teochew hawker dish of eggs, oysters, and a crispy-gooey batter made from sweet potato and rice flour. Served with tangy sambal chili sauce.

name: Chicken Satay (Singapore Style)
source: Adapted from Rasa Malaysia, Serious Eats, and Singapore Local Favourites.
description: Juicy, smoky grilled chicken skewers marinated in lemongrass, turmeric, and spices. Served with classic peanut sauce, cucumber, and onions.

name: Hainanese Chicken Rice
source: Adapted from Singapore hawker and home cook recipes.
description: Singapore’s iconic poached chicken and fragrant rice, served with chili sauce, ginger, and dark soy.

name: Fishball Noodles
source: Adapted from Singapore hawker and home cook recipes.
description: A beloved Singapore hawker dish of springy noodles tossed in savory sauce, served with bouncy fishballs, fishcake, and vegetables. Can be enjoyed dry or in soup.

name: Yong Tau Foo
source: Adapted from Singapore hawker and home cook recipes.
description: A healthy and customizable hawker favorite: tofu, vegetables, and beancurd skin stuffed with fish paste, served in a light broth with noodles or rice.

name: Lor Mee (Non-Vegetarian)
source: Adapted from Singapore hawker and home cook recipes.
description: A beloved Singapore hawker dish: thick yellow noodles in a savory, starchy gravy, topped with braised pork belly, egg, ngoh hiang, and condiments.

name: Chinese Rojak
source: Adapted from Singapore hawker and home cook recipes.
description: A beloved Singaporean hawker salad of fresh fruits, vegetables, and youtiao tossed in a sweet, tangy, and savory prawn paste sauce, topped with crushed peanuts.

name: Penang Char Kway Teow
source: Adapted from Penang hawker and home cook recipes.
description: A Penang hawker legend: flat rice noodles stir-fried over high heat with prawns, Chinese sausage, eggs, bean sprouts, and chives in a savory, smoky sauce.

name: White Bee Hoon
source: Adapted from Sembawang White Bee Hoon and Singapore zi char recipes.
description: A comforting Singapore zi char and hawker favorite: silky rice vermicelli braised in a light, savory seafood broth with prawns, squid, vegetables, and egg.

name: Chwee Jia Bao (Water Chestnut Bun)
source: Reconstructed from traditional Teochew/Chinese methods and Singaporean food history sources.
description: A traditional Teochew/Chinese steamed bun filled with sweet water chestnut paste. This bun is rare in modern Singapore, but was once a popular dim sum and festive treat. (Note: Authentic recipes are scarce; this is a reconstructed version based on traditional methods.)

name: Kong Ba Bao (Braised Pork Belly Bun)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Hokkien/Teochew home cooks.
description: A beloved Hokkien/Teochew dish in Singapore, featuring melt-in-your-mouth pork belly braised in soy sauce, spices, and aromatics, served in a fluffy steamed bun with pickled mustard greens. A festive and hawker favorite.

name: Wonton Mee (Wantan Mee)
source: Adapted from The Muddled Pantry and Nyonya Cooking, both reputable sources for Southeast Asian cuisine.
description: A beloved Singaporean and Malaysian noodle dish featuring springy egg noodles tossed in a savory soy sauce mixture, served with choy sum, char siu (Chinese BBQ pork), and delicate pork wontons, garnished with pickled green chillies.

name: Har Cheong Gai (Prawn Paste Chicken)
source: Adapted from Rasa Malaysia, The MeatMen, and Singapore zi char stalls.
description: A Singapore zi char and hawker favorite: crispy, juicy fried chicken wings marinated in fermented prawn paste, garlic, and spices. Served with lime and chili dip.

name: Claypot Rice (with Chicken and Chinese Sausage)
source: Adapted from The Woks of Life, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore hawker stalls.
description: A classic Cantonese-Singaporean dish: fragrant rice cooked in a claypot with marinated chicken, Chinese sausage, mushrooms, and salted fish. Finished with a savory soy sauce and crispy rice crust.

name: Steamed Minced Pork with Salted Egg (Hom Yee Jing Yuk Beng)
source: Adapted from The Woks of Life, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore home kitchens.
description: A comforting home-style dish: minced pork patty steamed with salted egg yolk, soy sauce, and white pepper. Juicy, savory, and perfect with rice.

name: Siew Mai (Pork and Shrimp Dumplings)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dim sum restaurants.
description: A classic Cantonese dim sum: open-faced dumplings filled with pork, shrimp, and mushrooms. Steamed and served with soy sauce or chili oil.

name: Har Gow (Shrimp Dumplings)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dim sum restaurants.
description: A dim sum favorite: translucent dumplings filled with shrimp and bamboo shoots, wrapped in a delicate wheat starch skin. Steamed and served hot.

name: Chee Cheong Fun (Rice Noodle Rolls)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dim sum stalls.
description: A Cantonese and local breakfast favorite: silky rice noodle rolls filled with shrimp, char siu, or plain, served with sweet soy sauce and sesame seeds.

name: Xiao Long Bao (Soup Dumplings)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dim sum restaurants.
description: A Shanghai specialty: delicate dumplings filled with pork and a rich, savory soup. Steamed and served with black vinegar and ginger.

name: Chicken Feet (Phoenix Claws)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dim sum restaurants.
description: A dim sum classic: chicken feet deep-fried, then braised in a savory black bean sauce until tender. Served at dim sum restaurants and hawker stalls.

name: Liu Sha Bao (Salted Egg Custard Buns)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dim sum bakeries.
description: A modern dim sum favorite: steamed buns filled with molten salted egg yolk custard. Soft, fluffy, and rich. Served at dim sum restaurants and bakeries.

name: Wolfberry Osmanthus Jelly
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dessert stalls.
description: A refreshing dim sum dessert: floral osmanthus jelly with wolfberries (goji berries). Served chilled at dim sum restaurants and dessert stalls.

name: Tofu Skin Rolls (Sin Juk Gyun)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dim sum restaurants.
description: A dim sum staple: beancurd skin rolls filled with pork, shrimp, and vegetables, steamed or fried. Served with soy sauce or chili.

name: Sesame Balls (Jian Dui)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore bakeries.
description: A popular dim sum and snack: deep-fried glutinous rice balls filled with sweet red bean paste, coated in sesame seeds. Crispy outside, chewy inside.

name: Shrimp Stuffed Eggplants
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore zi char stalls.
description: A dim sum and zi char favorite: eggplant slices stuffed with shrimp paste, pan-fried and served with savory sauce. Popular at hawker stalls and dim sum restaurants.

name: Red Bean Pancake (Wo Bing)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore bakeries.
description: A dim sum and snack favorite: crispy pan-fried pancakes filled with sweet red bean paste. Served at dim sum restaurants and bakeries.

name: Sugar Cane Prawn
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore zi char stalls.
description: A festive dim sum and zi char dish: shrimp paste molded around sugar cane sticks, steamed or fried. Sweet, savory, and aromatic.

name: Malay Steamed Cake (Ma Lai Gao)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dim sum bakeries.
description: A soft, fluffy Cantonese steamed cake with caramel flavor. Served at dim sum restaurants and bakeries in Singapore.

name: Ban Mian (Handmade Noodles)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore noodle stalls.
description: A hawker favorite: handmade wheat noodles served in a savory broth with pork, egg, vegetables, and anchovies. Popular at food courts and noodle stalls in Singapore.

name: Beef Kway Teow (Beef Hor Fun)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore hawker stalls.
description: A classic Singaporean hawker dish: silky flat rice noodles stir-fried with tender beef slices, bean sprouts, and a savory black bean sauce.

name: Curry Chicken Noodles
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore hawker stalls.
description: A comforting bowl of yellow noodles in a rich, spicy coconut curry broth with chicken, tau pok, and potatoes. A hawker favourite.

name: Orh Kueh (Steamed Yam Cake)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore hawker stalls.
description: A savory steamed cake made with yam, rice flour, and dried shrimp, topped with fried shallots and spring onions. Popular as a breakfast or snack.

name: Sliced Fish Soup in Milky Broth
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore hawker stalls.
description: A light, nourishing soup of fresh fish slices in a milky, peppery broth with vegetables and tofu. A hawker and home-cooked favourite.

name: Har Cheong Kai (Prawn Paste Fried Chicken)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore zi char stalls.
description: A beloved Singaporean zi char dish: chicken wings marinated in fermented prawn paste, then deep-fried until crispy and fragrant.

name: Chilled Tofu with Century Egg and Pickles
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore home kitchens.
description: A refreshing cold dish: silken tofu topped with diced century egg, pickled vegetables, and a savory soy dressing. Popular at Chinese restaurants and home tables.

name: Duck Roll Tempura
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore zi char stalls.
description: A creative fusion dish: shredded duck wrapped in beancurd skin, battered and deep-fried tempura-style. Crispy outside, juicy inside.

name: Char Siew (BBQ Pork)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore roast meat stalls.
description: A Cantonese classic: pork shoulder marinated in a sweet-savory sauce, roasted until caramelized and tender. A staple at Chinese roast meat stalls.

name: Crispy Roast Pork (Siu Yuk)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore roast meat stalls.
description: A Cantonese favourite: pork belly roasted until the skin is shatteringly crisp, with juicy, flavorful meat. Served at roast meat stalls and festive occasions.

name: Vinegar Pork Trotters (Zhu Jiao Cu)
source: Adapted from Singapore/Malaysia Chinese home cook recipes.
description: A traditional Chinese dish of pork trotters braised in sweet black vinegar, ginger, and eggs. Rich, tangy, and nourishing—especially popular as a confinement dish.

name: Sweet and Sour Pork (Gu Lou Yuk)
source: Adapted from Singapore zi char, Cantonese home cook, and restaurant recipes.
description: A Cantonese classic: crispy pork pieces tossed in a tangy, sweet, and savory sauce with pineapple, peppers, and onions. A favorite at Chinese restaurants and zi char stalls.

name: Sweet and Sour Fish (Tang Cu Yu)
source: Adapted from Singapore zi char, Cantonese home cook, and restaurant recipes.
description: A zi char and restaurant favorite: crispy fried fish fillets or whole fish, tossed in a tangy, sweet, and savory sauce with pineapple, peppers, and onions.

name: Stir-Fried Bittergourd with Egg (Ku Gua Chao Dan)
source: Adapted from Singapore/Malaysia Chinese home cook recipes.
description: A classic Chinese home-style stir-fry: tender, slightly bitter gourd slices tossed with fluffy scrambled eggs. Nutritious, quick, and comforting.

name: Stir-Fried Long Beans with Dried Shrimp (Gan Bian Si Ji Dou)
source: Adapted from Singapore/Malaysia Chinese home cook and zi char recipes.
description: A classic Chinese home-style and zi char dish: crisp-tender long beans stir-fried with aromatic dried shrimp, garlic, and a touch of chili. Savory, umami, and perfect with rice.

name: Steamed Egg Custard (Chawanmushi-style Chinese Egg)
source: Adapted from Singapore/Malaysia Chinese home cook recipes.
description: A classic Chinese home-style dish: silky, savory steamed egg custard, gently cooked to a delicate, just-set texture. Comforting, nutritious, and perfect with rice.

name: Mee Rebus

name: Mee Siam
source: Adapted from Singapore hawker and home cook recipes.

source: Adapted from Singapore hawker and home cook recipes.
description: A stir-fried version of Mee Siam, with rice vermicelli tossed in a spicy, tangy sauce, served dry with egg, tofu, and lime.

source: Adapted from Malaysian street burger stalls and home cook recipes.
description: A Malaysian street food icon: juicy beef or chicken patty, pan-fried and wrapped in an egg omelette, loaded with sauces, onions, and lettuce, all in a soft burger bun.

name: Sambal Goreng (Fried Tempeh and Tofu)
source: Adapted from Singapore/Malaysia Malay home cook recipes.
description: A classic Malay/Indonesian side dish: fried tempeh and tofu tossed in a spicy, aromatic sambal with onions and sometimes long beans or potatoes.

name: Arcot's Makkan Peda
source: https://www.sbs.com.au/food/recipes/makkan-peda-arcot-makkan-peda/
description: Eurasian-Indian festive sweet of stuffed milk dumplings soaked in rose-scented syrup.

name: Soup Kambing
source: https://www.noobcook.com/soup-kambing/
description: Spiced mutton soup with potatoes, carrots, and tomatoes, a South Indian-Muslim specialty.

name: Soup Tulang
source: https://www.noobcook.com/soup-tulang/
description: Spicy mutton bone marrow stew in a bright red, sweet-spicy sauce, a Singapore Indian-Muslim specialty.

name: Chicken Briyani
source: https://www.noobcook.com/chicken-biryani/
description: Fragrant basmati rice cooked with spiced chicken, saffron, and ghee, a festive Indian-Muslim dish.

name: Lamb Briyani
source: https://www.noobcook.com/lamb-biryani/
description: Fragrant basmati rice cooked with spiced lamb, saffron, and ghee, a festive Indian-Muslim dish.

name: Indian Rojak
source: https://www.noobcook.com/indian-rojak/
description: Assorted fried fritters, potatoes, eggs, and vegetables served with spicy peanut sauce, a vibrant Indian-Muslim salad.

name: Butter Chicken (Murgh Makhani)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian restaurants.
description: A North Indian favorite: tender chicken in a creamy, spiced tomato sauce. Served with naan or rice at Indian restaurants in Singapore.

name: Chicken Tandoori
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian restaurants.
description: A classic North Indian grilled chicken, marinated in yogurt and spices, cooked in a tandoor or oven. Juicy, smoky, and deeply flavorful. Popular at Indian restaurants and mamak stalls in Singapore.

name: Idli with Sambar
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian restaurants.
description: A South Indian breakfast staple: steamed rice cakes (idli) served with spicy lentil-vegetable stew (sambar). Popular at Indian restaurants and hawker stalls in Singapore.

name: Naan (Indian Leavened Flatbread)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian restaurants.
description: A classic Indian leavened flatbread, soft and fluffy with a slight char, perfect for pairing with curries. Popular at Indian restaurants and mamak stalls in Singapore.

name: Palak Paneer
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian restaurants.
description: A North Indian vegetarian classic: paneer cubes simmered in a creamy spinach gravy. Served with naan or rice at Indian restaurants in Singapore.

name: Pani Puri
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian restaurants.
description: A popular Indian street snack: crisp puris filled with spicy, tangy water, potatoes, and chickpeas. Enjoyed at Indian restaurants and food stalls in Singapore.

name: Samosa
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian kitchens.
description: A classic Indian snack: crisp pastry filled with spiced potatoes and peas, deep-fried until golden. Popular at Indian restaurants and snack stalls in Singapore.

name: Satti Sorru (Claypot Rice)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian restaurants.
description: A South Indian specialty: rice cooked in a claypot with mutton, spices, and herbs. Fragrant, spicy, and deeply flavorful. Popular at Indian restaurants and food stalls in Singapore.

name: Thosai (Dosa)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian restaurants.
description: A classic South Indian crepe made from fermented rice and urad dal batter. Crispy, tangy, and served with chutney and sambar. Popular at Indian restaurants and hawker stalls in Singapore.

name: Dum Briyani (Biryani)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian restaurants.
description: A festive Indian rice dish: fragrant basmati rice layered with spiced mutton or chicken, cooked on dum (sealed pot). Served at weddings, festivals, and Indian restaurants in Singapore.

name: Ayam Buah Keluak
source: https://www.noobcook.com/ayam-buah-keluak/
description: Classic Peranakan chicken stew with earthy buah keluak nuts, pork, and aromatic spices.

name: Babi Pong Tay
source: https://www.noobcook.com/babi-pong-tay/
description: Peranakan braised pork belly with fermented bean paste, mushrooms, and potatoes.

name: Kueh Pie Tee
source: https://www.noobcook.com/kueh-pie-tee/
description: Crispy pastry cups filled with braised turnip, carrots, and prawns, topped with chili and coriander, a Peranakan party favorite.

name: Perut Ikan
source: https://www.noobcook.com/perut-ikan/
description: Peranakan spicy and tangy curry of pickled fish stomach, vegetables, and aromatic herbs.

name: Kerabu Bee Hoon
source: https://www.noobcook.com/kerabu-bee-hoon/
description: Peranakan cold rice vermicelli salad with herbs, prawns, and a tangy spicy dressing.

name: Semur (Peranakan Beef Stew)
source: Adapted from Nyonya Cooking, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Peranakan kitchens.
description: A rich, aromatic Peranakan stew of beef braised with sweet soy sauce, potatoes, tomatoes, and spices. Sweet, savory, and deeply comforting.

name: Putugal (Steamed Tapioca Banana Kueh)
source: Adapted from Eurasian and Peranakan home kitchens, Nyonya Cooking.
description: A traditional Eurasian and Peranakan steamed kueh made with tapioca, banana, and coconut, colored blue with butterfly pea flower. Soft, chewy, and lightly sweet.

name: Lor Kai Yik (Braised Chicken and Tofu in Red Fermented Bean Curd)
source: Adapted from Nyonya Cooking, The MeatMen, and Singapore Peranakan kitchens.
description: A unique Hokkien-Peranakan dish: chicken, tofu, and vegetables braised in a savory-sweet sauce with red fermented bean curd, garlic, and five spice. Rich, tangy, and deeply flavorful.

name: Ngoh Hiang (Five-Spice Meat Rolls)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Peranakan kitchens.
description: A classic Peranakan and Teochew dish: minced pork, prawn, and water chestnut seasoned with five spice, wrapped in beancurd skin and deep-fried. Served with sweet sauce and chili.

name: Hae Cho (Prawn Rolls)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Teochew kitchens.
description: A Teochew and Peranakan favorite: prawn and pork rolls seasoned with five spice, wrapped in beancurd skin and deep-fried. Served at festive occasions and as a snack.

name: Peng Kueh (Pink Rice Dumplings)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Teochew kitchens.
description: A Teochew and Peranakan snack: pink steamed dumplings filled with glutinous rice, mushrooms, peanuts, and dried shrimp. Served at breakfast and snack stalls.

name: Soon Kueh (Bamboo Shoot Dumplings)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Teochew kitchens.
description: A Teochew and Peranakan snack: steamed dumplings filled with bamboo shoots, jicama, and dried shrimp. Served at breakfast and snack stalls.

name: Inchi Kabin (Nyonya Fried Chicken)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Penang Nyonya kitchens.
description: A Penang Nyonya specialty: spiced fried chicken marinated with coconut milk, five spice, and aromatics. Crispy, juicy, and fragrant.

name: Bak Chang (Nyonya Rice Dumplings)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Penang Nyonya kitchens.
description: A festive Peranakan dumpling: glutinous rice filled with pork, candied winter melon, mushrooms, and spices, wrapped in bamboo leaves and boiled. Distinctive blue from butterfly pea flower.

name: Babi Assam (Tamarind Pork)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Peranakan kitchens.
description: A tangy, aromatic Peranakan stew: pork belly braised with tamarind, chilies, and spices. Served with rice at Nyonya homes.

name: Itek Tim (Salted Vegetable Duck Soup)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Peranakan kitchens.
description: A classic Peranakan soup: duck simmered with salted vegetables, tomatoes, and sour plums. Tangy, savory, and comforting.

name: Seh Bak (Nyonya Braised Pork Belly)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Penang Nyonya kitchens.
description: A Penang Nyonya favorite: pork belly braised with five spice, garlic, and soy sauce. Rich, savory, and melt-in-your-mouth.

name: Swikee (Frog Leg Soup)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Peranakan kitchens.
description: A Peranakan and Indonesian specialty: frog legs simmered in a ginger-garlic broth with Chinese celery and white pepper. Delicate, savory, and warming.

name: Kueh Salat (Kuih Seri Muka)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore kueh stalls.
description: A classic Peranakan kueh: two layers of glutinous rice and pandan custard, rich, fragrant, and colorful. Served at festive occasions and kueh stalls.

name: Kari Kapitan (Nyonya Chicken Curry)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Peranakan kitchens.
description: A rich, aromatic Peranakan chicken curry with coconut milk, candlenuts, and spices. Served with rice or bread at Nyonya homes.

name: Nyonya Stewed Pork Ribs
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Peranakan kitchens.
description: A comforting Peranakan stew: pork ribs braised with soy sauce, garlic, and spices. Tender, savory, and perfect with rice.

name: Asam Prawn (Tamarind Prawns)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Peranakan kitchens.
description: A tangy, savory Peranakan dish: prawns marinated in tamarind and sugar, pan-fried until caramelized. Served with rice at Nyonya homes.

name: Lor Bak (Nyonya Braised Pork)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Penang Nyonya kitchens.
description: A Penang Nyonya classic: pork belly braised with five spice, soy sauce, and garlic. Rich, savory, and melt-in-your-mouth.

name: Kueh Dadar (Pandan Coconut Crepes)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore kueh stalls.
description: A Peranakan and Malay kueh: pandan crepes filled with sweet coconut and palm sugar. Soft, fragrant, and colorful. Served at kueh stalls and festive occasions.

name: Kueh Talam (Pandan Coconut Layer Cake)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore kueh stalls.
description: A Peranakan kueh: two layers of pandan and coconut, steamed until set. Soft, fragrant, and colorful. Served at kueh stalls and festive occasions.

name: Udang Masak Nanas (Pineapple Prawn Curry)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Peranakan kitchens.
description: A tangy, aromatic Peranakan curry: prawns and pineapple simmered in a spicy coconut gravy. Served with rice at Nyonya homes.

name: Belimbing Masak Lemak (Starfruit in Coconut Gravy)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Peranakan kitchens.
description: A unique Peranakan and Malay dish: starfruit (belimbing) cooked in a spicy, creamy coconut gravy with dried shrimp and turmeric. Served with rice.

name: Kiam Chye Buey (Peranakan Mustard Green Stew)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Peranakan kitchens.
description: A tangy, savory stew of leftover roast meats, salted mustard greens, tomatoes, and tamarind. Served at Peranakan homes after festive feasts.

name: Bakwan Kepiting (Crabmeat Meatball Soup)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Peranakan kitchens.
description: A festive Peranakan soup: pork and crabmeat balls simmered in a clear broth with bamboo shoots and vegetables. Served at celebrations and family gatherings.

name: Nasi Ulam (Herbed Rice Salad)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Peranakan kitchens.
description: A refreshing Peranakan salad: rice tossed with a medley of fresh herbs, dried shrimp, and toasted coconut. Served at festive occasions and potlucks.

name: Pineapple Fried Rice (Nasi Goreng Nanas)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Peranakan kitchens.
description: A festive Peranakan and Thai-inspired fried rice: rice stir-fried with pineapple, prawns, cashews, and spices. Served in a pineapple shell at parties.

name: Buah Papaya Masak Titek (Peppery Papaya Soup)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Eurasian/Peranakan kitchens.
description: A classic Eurasian and Peranakan soup: green papaya simmered with pork ribs, white pepper, and garlic. Peppery, savory, and comforting.

name: Kuih Bongkong (Steamed Coconut Pudding)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore kueh stalls.
description: A traditional Peranakan and Malay kueh: steamed coconut pudding with gula melaka, wrapped in banana leaves. Soft, fragrant, and lightly sweet.

name: Feng (Eurasian Christmas Stew)
source: https://www.sbs.com.au/food/recipes/feng-eurasian-christmas-stew/
description: Rich, spicy stew of pork, liver, and spices, a Eurasian Christmas classic.

name: Sugee Cake
source: https://www.noobcook.com/sugee-cake/
description: Rich, buttery semolina cake with ground almonds, a Eurasian festive treat.

name: Shepherd's Pie (Eurasian Style)
source: Adapted from Serious Eats and Tatyana's Everyday Food, both reputable sources for classic and Eurasian-style Shepherd's Pie.
description: A comforting Eurasian-style Shepherd's Pie with a rich lamb or beef filling, carrots, peas, and onions, topped with creamy mashed potatoes and baked until golden. Adapted from classic British and Eurasian home recipes.

name: Eurasian Sugee Cake (Semolina and Almond Cake)
source: Adapted from LinsFood, Cheryl Marie Cordeiro, and Taste Cooking.
description: A rich, buttery, and nutty semolina cake with ground almonds, brandy, and eggs. A Eurasian celebration classic for weddings, Christmas, and birthdays in Singapore and Malaysia.

name: Hakka Fried Pork (Zha Yuk)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Nyonya Cooking, and Eurasian home kitchens.
description: A Hakka and Eurasian favorite: pork belly marinated with red fermented bean curd, five spice, and rice wine, then deep-fried until crispy. Served with rice or as part of festive meals.

name: Yi Bua (Glutinous Rice Cake with Coconut and Peanut Filling)
source: Adapted from Hakka and Eurasian home kitchens, The MeatMen.
description: A traditional Hakka and Eurasian steamed kueh: glutinous rice flour dough filled with sweet coconut, peanut, and sesame, wrapped in banana leaf and steamed. Soft, chewy, and aromatic.

name: Muah Chee (Glutinous Rice Snack)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Teochew home cooks.
description: A beloved Teochew/Chinese snack in Singapore, made from steamed glutinous rice dough cut into bite-sized pieces and coated in fragrant peanut-sugar. Soft, chewy, and nutty, it's a hawker and pasar malam favorite.

name: Pig Blood Pudding (Zhu Xue Gao)
source: Reconstructed from traditional Teochew/Chinese methods and Singaporean food history sources.
description: A traditional Teochew/Chinese street snack once found in Singapore, made from steamed or boiled pig's blood, cut into cubes and served with soy sauce, chili, and coriander. (Note: Authentic recipes are rare and this dish is now largely unavailable in Singapore; this is a reconstructed version for historical reference.)

name: Curry Puff (Karipap)
source: Adapted from Rasa Malaysia, Taste Asian Food, and The Spruce Eats, all reputable sources for Southeast Asian snacks.
description: A beloved Singaporean and Malaysian street snack: golden, flaky pastry filled with curried potatoes, chicken, and onions. Deep-fried for a crisp, layered shell. Iconic at hawker stalls and bakeries.

name: Singapore Popiah (Fresh Spring Rolls)
source: Adapted from Stream of Flavors, HungryGoWhere, and Singapore Noodles.
description: A beloved Singaporean street food: thin wheat crepes filled with braised jicama, carrots, turnip, prawns, egg, lettuce, bean sprouts, and peanuts. Served with sweet sauce, chili, and garlic paste. Popular at hawker centers and family gatherings.

name: Tau Sar Piah (Mung Bean Pastry) [See Desserts & Sweets]
description: A flaky, layered pastry with sweet or savory mung bean filling. Popular as a street snack and festive treat in Singapore. See full recipe in Desserts and Sweets category (des_021).

name: Otak Otak (Grilled Fish Cake in Banana Leaf)
source: Adapted from Rasa Malaysia, The MeatMen, and Singapore hawker stalls.
description: A spicy, aromatic fish cake mixture wrapped in banana leaves and grilled. Made with mackerel, coconut milk, spices, and herbs. A classic street snack in Singapore and Malaysia.

name: Roti John (Singapore Omelette Sandwich)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore hawker stalls.
description: A popular street food: baguette or soft roll filled with spiced minced meat, onions, and egg, pan-fried until golden, and topped with chili sauce and mayonnaise.

name: Murtabak (Stuffed Pan-Fried Flatbread)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore mamak stalls.
description: A hearty street food: thin dough stuffed with spiced minced meat, onions, and egg, pan-fried until crisp. Served with curry sauce or pickled onions.

name: Roti Jala (Lacy Crepes)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Malay kitchens.
description: A festive Malay and Peranakan snack: delicate, lacy crepes made from a turmeric-flavored batter, served with curry. Popular at celebrations and as a street food treat.

name: Ba Kwa (BBQ Pork Jerky)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore snack shops.
description: A festive Chinese-Singaporean snack: sweet-salty BBQ pork jerky, grilled to smoky perfection. Iconic during Lunar New Year and at snack shops.

name: Tau Kwa Pau (Stuffed Beancurd)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Teochew stalls.
description: A Teochew hawker snack: fried beancurd stuffed with braised egg, cucumber, yam, and pork, served with sweet sauce and chili. Unique to Singapore.

name: Ice Gem Biscuits
source: Adapted from Singapore bakeries and home kitchens.
description: A nostalgic childhood snack: tiny crunchy biscuits topped with colorful icing gems. Popular at provision shops and bakeries.

name: Murukku
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian kitchens.
description: A crunchy Indian snack: deep-fried spirals of rice and urad dal flour, spiced with cumin and chili. Popular during Deepavali and at snack stalls.

name: Ondeh Ondeh
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Peranakan kitchens.
description: A beloved Peranakan and Malay kueh: glutinous rice balls filled with molten palm sugar, coated in grated coconut. Chewy, sweet, and fragrant.

name: Butterfly Buns (You Char Kway Butterfly)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore hawker stalls.
description: A hawker favorite: sweet, deep-fried buns shaped like butterflies, often paired with youtiao. Soft, fluffy, and lightly sweet.

name: Youtiao (Chinese Fried Dough Sticks)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore breakfast stalls.
description: A classic breakfast snack: long, golden fried dough sticks, crisp outside and airy inside. Served with porridge or soy milk.

name: Goreng Pisang (Fried Banana Fritters)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Malay stalls.
description: A popular Malay snack: ripe bananas coated in a light batter and deep-fried until golden. Crispy outside, sweet and soft inside.

name: Begedil (Potato Patties)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore nasi padang stalls.
description: A Malay and Indonesian snack: deep-fried potato patties, sometimes with minced beef, served with soto or as a side. Popular at nasi padang stalls in Singapore.

name: Ikan Bilis with Peanuts
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore nasi lemak stalls.
description: A classic Malay and Nasi Lemak side: crispy fried anchovies and peanuts tossed with chili and sugar. Served at breakfast and snack stalls in Singapore.

name: Bergedil Jagung (Corn Potato Patties)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Malay stalls.
description: A Malay snack: deep-fried patties of potato and sweet corn, served as a side or snack. Popular at Malay food stalls in Singapore.

name: Min Jiang Kueh (Peanut Pancake)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore breakfast stalls.
description: A popular Singaporean snack: thick, fluffy pancake filled with crushed peanuts and sugar. Sold at hawker breakfast stalls and markets.

name: Fuzhou Oyster Cake (Oyster Puff)
source: Adapted from Singapore Fuzhou hawker and home cook recipes.
description: A crispy, savory Fuzhou snack: deep-fried batter filled with oysters, minced pork, prawns, chives, and peanuts. A rare treat at Singapore hawker centers.

name: Sweet Potato Balls
source: Adapted from Singapore/Malaysia/Taiwan street snack recipes.
description: A popular street snack: golden, crispy balls made from mashed sweet potato and tapioca flour, lightly sweet and delightfully chewy.

name: Pengat Pisang (Banana Coconut Dessert)
source: Adapted from Serious Eats, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore/Malaysia home cooks.
description: A classic Malay and Peranakan dessert popular in Singapore, featuring ripe bananas gently simmered in coconut milk with palm sugar and sago pearls. Served warm or chilled, this sweet soup is a nostalgic treat at home and festive gatherings.

name: Kueh Abuk Abuk Sagu (Steamed Sago Cake)
source: Adapted from Rasa Malaysia, The MeatMen, and Singapore/Malay/Peranakan home cooks.
description: A traditional Malay/Peranakan steamed kueh made from sago pearls, grated coconut, and palm sugar, wrapped in banana leaves and steamed. Chewy, fragrant, and sweet, it's a festive treat in Singapore and Malaysia.

name: Gingko Nut Barley (Fu Chok Yi Mai)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Chinese home cooks.
description: A classic Chinese dessert soup in Singapore, featuring barley, dried bean curd sheets, and gingko nuts simmered in a lightly sweet broth. Nourishing, cooling, and popular at dessert stalls.

name: Tau Suan (Split Mung Bean Dessert)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Chinese home cooks.
description: A beloved Teochew/Chinese dessert in Singapore, featuring split mung beans cooked until just tender, thickened with sweet potato flour, and served with fried dough sticks (youtiao). Sweet, silky, and comforting.

name: Papaya Milk Sago
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Chinese home cooks.
description: A refreshing Singaporean/Chinese dessert featuring chewy sago pearls, ripe papaya, and creamy milk or coconut milk, lightly sweetened and served chilled. Popular at dessert stalls and as a cooling treat.

name: Watermelon Milk Sago
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Chinese home cooks.
description: A cooling Singaporean/Chinese dessert featuring chewy sago pearls, juicy watermelon, and creamy milk or coconut milk, lightly sweetened and served chilled. Perfect for hot days and dessert stalls.

name: Durian Pengat
source: Adapted from Camemberu, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore home cooks.
description: A rich, creamy, and decadent dessert made from fresh durian, coconut cream, and palm sugar. A Peranakan and Malay favorite, especially during durian season.

name: Chendol
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, My Singapore Food, SBS, and Singapore home cooks.
description: A beloved shaved ice dessert with pandan jelly noodles, coconut milk, and palm sugar syrup. Iconic at hawker centers and dessert stalls.

name: Ice Kacang (Ais Kacang)
source: Adapted from Rasa Malaysia, What To Cook Today, Serious Eats, and Singapore home cooks.
description: A mountain of shaved ice with sweet syrups, red beans, grass jelly, sweet corn, and more. A colorful, refreshing Singaporean and Malaysian dessert.

name: Bubur Cha Cha
source: Adapted from Rasa Malaysia, The MeatMen, and Singapore home cooks.
description: A vibrant Nyonya dessert soup of sweet potatoes, yam, sago, and colorful tapioca jellies in coconut milk. Served warm or cold.

name: Pulut Hitam (Black Glutinous Rice Dessert)
source: Adapted from Rasa Malaysia, The MeatMen, and Singapore home cooks.
description: A comforting dessert of black glutinous rice slow-cooked with coconut milk and palm sugar. Served warm or cold.

name: Kueh Lapis (Layer Cake)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore home cooks.
description: A festive steamed cake with colorful layers of coconut and rice flour, flavored with pandan and coconut milk. Chewy, sweet, and nostalgic.

name: Ondeh Ondeh
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore home cooks.
description: Chewy glutinous rice balls filled with molten palm sugar and coated in fresh coconut. A bite-sized Peranakan and Malay treat.

name: Sago Gula Melaka
source: Adapted from Rasa Malaysia, The MeatMen, and Singapore home cooks.
description: A simple yet decadent dessert of sago pearls topped with coconut milk and palm sugar syrup. Served chilled.

name: Cheng Tng (Clear Sweet Soup)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dessert stalls.
description: A refreshing Teochew dessert soup: dried longan, barley, lotus seeds, white fungus, and sweet potato simmered in a light syrup. Served hot or cold at dessert stalls.

name: Red Bean Soup (Hong Dou Tang)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore home cooks.
description: A classic Chinese dessert soup of red beans simmered with dried tangerine peel and rock sugar. Served hot or cold.

name: Mango Pomelo Sago
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dessert shops.
description: A refreshing dessert of mango puree, pomelo sacs, sago pearls, and coconut milk. Served chilled, popular at dessert shops.

name: Orh Nee (Yam Paste)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Teochew restaurants.
description: A Teochew classic dessert of steamed yam paste, sweetened and enriched with lard or coconut milk, topped with ginkgo nuts.

name: Sweet Corn Ice Cream
source: Adapted from Cook Republic, Singapore hawker stalls, and home cooks.
description: A nostalgic Singaporean treat: creamy ice cream made with sweet corn, coconut cream, and milk powder. Served in a cup or as an ice cream sandwich.

name: Ang Ku Kueh (Red Tortoise Cake)
source: Adapted from Rasa Malaysia, Nyonya Cooking, and Singapore Infopedia.
description: A traditional Peranakan and Chinese pastry with a soft, chewy glutinous rice flour skin and sweet mung bean or peanut filling. Molded to resemble a tortoise shell and served at celebrations for good luck.

name: Tau Sar Piah (Mung Bean Pastry)
source: Adapted from Nyonya Cooking, The MeatMen, and Singapore Infopedia.
description: A flaky, layered pastry filled with sweet or savory mung bean paste. Popular as a snack or festive treat in Singapore and Malaysia, especially during Chinese festivals.

name: Kueh Abuk-Abuk Sagu (Steamed Sago Cake)
source: Adapted from Nyonya Cooking, The MeatMen, and Singapore Malay kitchens.
description: A traditional Malay and Peranakan steamed kueh made with sago pearls, grated coconut, and palm sugar, wrapped in banana leaves. Chewy, fragrant, and lightly sweet.

name: Putu Piring (Steamed Rice Flour Cake with Palm Sugar)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Malay/Indian stalls.
description: A beloved Malay and Indian steamed cake: soft rice flour discs filled with molten palm sugar, steamed and served with grated coconut. Iconic at pasar malams and hawker stalls.

name: Frog Leg Porridge (Tian Ji Zhou)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore supper stalls.
description: A comforting Teochew-style porridge with tender frog legs, ginger, spring onions, and a savory soy-based sauce. A supper favorite at Singapore hawker stalls.

name: Chin Chow (Grass Jelly Dessert)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dessert stalls.
description: A cooling dessert: grass jelly cubes served with syrup and sometimes longan or attap seeds. Popular at hawker dessert stalls.

name: Cheng Tng (Clear Sweet Soup)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dessert stalls.
description: A refreshing Teochew dessert soup: dried longan, barley, lotus seeds, white fungus, and sweet potato simmered in a light syrup. Served hot or cold at dessert stalls.

name: Tang Yuan (Glutinous Rice Balls in Syrup)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dessert stalls.
description: A festive Chinese dessert: glutinous rice balls filled with black sesame or peanut, served in a sweet ginger syrup. Popular during Dongzhi and at dessert stalls.

name: Gulab Jamun
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian kitchens.
description: A classic Indian sweet: deep-fried milk balls soaked in cardamom-scented syrup. Popular at Indian restaurants and during Deepavali in Singapore.

name: Mango Pudding
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dessert stalls.
description: A creamy, fruity dessert: mango puree set with gelatin and milk, served chilled. Popular at Chinese restaurants and dessert stalls.

name: Tapioca Cake (Kueh Ubi Kayu)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Peranakan kitchens.
description: A traditional Peranakan and Malay kueh: steamed grated tapioca cake with coconut and sugar, sometimes colored with pandan. Chewy, sweet, and fragrant.

name: Kueh Tutu
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore snack stalls.
description: A nostalgic street snack: steamed rice flour cakes filled with grated coconut or peanut. Soft, fluffy, and lightly sweet. Iconic at pasar malams and snack stalls.

name: Kuih Kosui
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Peranakan kitchens.
description: A Peranakan steamed cake: soft, bouncy cakes made from rice flour, tapioca flour, and palm sugar, coated in grated coconut. Served at kueh stalls and festive occasions.

name: Sago Gula Melaka
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Peranakan kitchens.
description: A classic Peranakan dessert: sago pearls served with coconut milk and palm sugar syrup. Chewy, creamy, and fragrant.

name: Mee Jiang Kueh (Peanut Pancake)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore breakfast stalls.
description: A popular breakfast snack: thick, fluffy pancake filled with crushed peanuts and sugar. Sold at hawker breakfast stalls and markets.

name: Tau Huey (Soybean Pudding)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore dessert stalls.
description: A classic Singaporean dessert: silky smooth soybean pudding served with a light sugar syrup. Popular at dessert stalls and breakfast shops.

name: Turtle Soup
source: https://www.noobcook.com/turtle-soup/
description: Traditional herbal soup made with softshell turtle meat, Chinese herbs, and wolfberries.

name: Bak Kut Teh (Pork Rib Tea Soup)
source: Adapted from The Burning Kitchen, Nyonya Cooking, and Serious Eats
description: A classic Singaporean-Teochew soup of pork ribs simmered with garlic, white pepper, and a blend of Chinese herbs. Served with rice, youtiao (fried dough), and a chili-soy dip. Warming, peppery, and deeply comforting.

name: Fish Head Curry (Singapore Style)
source: Adapted from Serious Eats, Marion's Kitchen, and Foodelicacy
description: A signature Singaporean dish blending South Indian curry with Chinese-style fish head. Features snapper head, eggplant, okra, tomatoes, and a rich coconut-tamarind curry. Served bubbling hot with rice or roti.

name: Soto Ayam (Singapore/Malay Chicken Noodle Soup)
source: Adapted from Nomadette, Serious Eats, and Wikipedia.
description: A beloved Singaporean-Malay chicken noodle soup with a clear, aromatic broth, shredded chicken, yellow noodles or vermicelli, and a spicy-sweet sambal kicap. Served with beansprouts, fried shallots, and lime.

name: Pig Stomach Soup (Bak Kut Teh Style)
source: https://www.noobcook.com/pig-stomach-soup/
description: A classic Teochew/Chinese soup featuring pig stomach simmered with white pepper, garlic, and pork ribs. Served hot with rice and youtiao.

name: Kway Chap (Braised Pig Offal with Flat Rice Noodles)
source: https://www.noobcook.com/kway-chap/
description: A Teochew hawker classic: pig offal, pork belly, and tofu braised in a savory soy-based gravy, served with flat rice noodles (kway chap).

name: Bird Nest Soup
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore banquet kitchens.
description: A luxurious Chinese delicacy: double-boiled bird's nest with rock sugar, prized for its texture and health benefits. Served at banquets and special occasions.

name: Buddha Jumps Over the Wall
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore banquet kitchens.
description: A legendary Fujianese banquet soup: abalone, sea cucumber, fish maw, dried scallops, mushrooms, and more, simmered in a rich broth. Served at special occasions in Singapore.

name: Braised Sea Treasure Soup
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore banquet kitchens.
description: A luxurious seafood soup: fish maw, dried scallops, crab meat, prawns, and mushrooms in a thick, savory broth. Served at banquets and festive occasions.

name: Suan La Tang (Hot and Sour Soup)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Chinese restaurants.
description: A popular Chinese soup: spicy, tangy broth with tofu, mushrooms, bamboo shoots, and egg. Served at Chinese restaurants and home kitchens in Singapore.

name: Herbal Chicken (Yao Ji)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Singapore home kitchens, and TCM recipes.
description: A nourishing Chinese herbal soup: whole chicken braised with Chinese herbs, red dates, goji berries, and dang gui. Tonic, restorative, and deeply flavorful. Popular at home and herbal soup stalls.

name: ABC Soup (Potato, Carrot, Onion Soup)
source: Adapted from Singapore/Malaysia Chinese home cook recipes.
description: A nourishing, clear Chinese soup with potatoes, carrots, onions, and tomatoes, simmered with pork ribs or chicken. A family favorite for all ages.

name: Lotus Root Soup with Pork Ribs
source: Adapted from Singapore/Malaysia Chinese home cook recipes.
description: A traditional Chinese home-style soup: pork ribs simmered with lotus root, peanuts, and red dates for a sweet, earthy, and nourishing broth.

name: Winter Melon Soup
source: Adapted from Singapore/Malaysia Chinese home cook recipes.
description: A light, cooling Chinese soup with winter melon, pork ribs, dried shrimp, and mushrooms. Nourishing and perfect for hot weather.

name: Foochow Red Wine Mee Sua (福州红糟鸡面线)
source: Adapted from What To Cook Today, NoobCook, and Singapore/Malaysia Foochow home cooks.
description: A traditional Foochow (Fuzhou) dish beloved in Singapore, featuring chicken braised in homemade red glutinous rice wine and served with silky wheat vermicelli (mee sua). Popular for celebrations and confinement, this dish is prized for its warming, aromatic broth and tender chicken.

name: Fen Ti (Glass Noodles with Minced Pork)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Chinese home cooks.
description: A comforting Chinese home-style dish in Singapore, featuring glass noodles (mung bean vermicelli) stir-fried with minced pork, mushrooms, and aromatics. Savory, silky, and satisfying.

name: Pumpkin Rice (Nankua Fan)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Chinese home cooks.
description: A comforting Chinese home-style dish in Singapore, featuring rice cooked with pumpkin, dried shrimp, mushrooms, and aromatics. Savory, sweet, and hearty, it's a favorite at home and hawker stalls.

name: Yam Rice (Orh Nee Fan)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Chinese home cooks.
description: A hearty Teochew/Chinese rice dish in Singapore, featuring rice cooked with yam, dried shrimp, mushrooms, and aromatics. Savory, earthy, and perfect with braised duck or pork dishes.

name: Braised Ee Mien (E-Fu Noodles)
source: https://theninjacook.weebly.com/culinary-adventures/braised-e-fu-noodles
description: A classic banquet and hawker dish of braised E-Fu (Ee Mien) noodles, stir-fried with garlic chives, mushrooms, and a savory sauce. Soft, springy noodles with a rich umami flavor, often served at celebrations.

name: Sheng Mian (Crispy/Soft-Fried Noodles)
source: https://www.noobcook.com/sheng-mian/
description: A Singaporean zi char classic: egg noodles fried until crispy or soft, topped with a savory gravy of seafood, pork, and vegetables. Known for its textural contrast and rich, silky sauce.

name: Yangzhou Fried Rice (Yang Chow Chao Fan)
source: https://www.julieolive.co.uk/2023/05/09/traditional-yang-chow-yangzhou-fried-rice-%E6%89%AC%E5%B7%9E%E7%82%92%E9%A5%AD/
description: A beloved fried rice dish with origins in Yangzhou, China, but a staple at Singapore zi char stalls. Features fluffy rice, prawns, char siu, egg, and vegetables, all tossed with a hint of rice wine.

name: XO Fish Head Bee Hoon
source: https://whattocooktoday.com/xo-fish-bee-hoon-soup.html
description: A luxurious Singaporean noodle soup featuring fried fish head or fillet, thick bee hoon (rice vermicelli), choy sum, tomatoes, and a milky, aromatic broth enriched with XO cognac.

name: Laksa
source: https://www.seriouseats.com/singapore-laksa-recipe
description: Spicy coconut curry noodle soup with prawns, fish cakes, and cockles.

name: Katong Laksa
source: https://ieatishootipost.sg/katong-laksa-recipe/
description: Famous Singaporean laksa with thick rice noodles, prawns, fish cake, and spicy coconut broth.

name: Satay Bee Hoon
source: https://www.noobcook.com/satay-bee-hoon/
description: Rice vermicelli topped with a spicy peanut satay sauce, cuttlefish, cockles, and vegetables.

name: Singapore Prawn Noodles (Hae Mee)
source: Adapted from Rasa Malaysia, The MeatMen, and Singapore hawker stalls.
description: A beloved Singaporean hawker noodle soup featuring a rich, aromatic prawn and pork broth, yellow noodles, prawns, pork slices, bean sprouts, and fried shallots. Served with spicy sambal and lime.

name: Chicken Claypot Rice (Claypot Ji Fan)
source: Adapted from The Woks of Life, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore hawker stalls.
description: A classic Cantonese-Singaporean dish: fragrant rice cooked in a claypot with marinated chicken, Chinese sausage, mushrooms, and salted fish. Finished with a savory soy sauce and crispy rice crust.

name: Black Chicken Herbal Soup (Wu Ji Tang)
source: Adapted from The Woks of Life, Singapore home kitchens, and TCM recipes.
description: A nourishing Chinese herbal soup made with black chicken (silkie), red dates, goji berries, and a blend of traditional herbs. Tonic, restorative, and deeply flavorful.

name: Chao Tah Bee Hoon (Crispy Rice Vermicelli Cake)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Teochew restaurants.
description: A Teochew-Singaporean specialty: rice vermicelli pressed and pan-fried until crispy on the outside, soft inside, served with seafood, pork, and vegetables in a savory gravy.

name: Suan Pan Zi (Abacus Seeds)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Hakka kitchens.
description: A classic Hakka dish popular in Singapore: chewy yam abacus seeds stir-fried with minced pork, mushrooms, dried shrimp, and black fungus. Symbolizes wealth and reunion.

name: Salt Baked Chicken (Yim Guk Gai)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Singapore Teochew and Cantonese kitchens.
description: A Teochew and Cantonese favorite in Singapore: whole chicken marinated with Chinese herbs, wrapped, and baked in salt for juicy, aromatic meat. Often served at hawker stalls and home feasts.

name: Roti Prata
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore mamak stalls.
description: A beloved Indian-Singaporean flatbread: crispy outside, soft and chewy inside. Served with curry or sugar, a breakfast and supper staple at mamak stalls.

name: Bak Chor Mee (Minced Pork Noodles)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore hawker stalls.
description: A beloved Teochew noodle dish: springy noodles tossed in vinegar, chili, and lard, topped with minced pork, mushrooms, fish balls, and crispy shallots. Iconic at Singapore hawker stalls.

name: Chwee Kueh (Steamed Rice Cakes with Preserved Radish)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore breakfast stalls.
description: A classic Teochew breakfast: soft, steamed rice cakes topped with savory chye poh (preserved radish) and chili. Popular at hawker breakfast stalls.

name: Penang Laksa (Assam Laksa)
source: Adapted from Penang hawker and home cook recipes.
description: A tangy, spicy noodle soup from Penang, Malaysia, featuring rice noodles in a tamarind-mackerel broth, topped with pineapple, cucumber, mint, and torch ginger.

name: Hainanese Pork Chop (海南猪排)
source: Adapted from What To Cook Today, My Singapore Food, and TasteAsianFood.com.
description: A classic Singaporean Hainanese-Western fusion dish: pork chops marinated, breaded with cream crackers, deep-fried, and served with a tangy tomato-based gravy, potatoes, and peas. A nostalgic favorite at old-school coffee houses and Hainanese-run Western stalls.

name: Salt Baked Chicken (盐焗鸡, Yán Jū Jī)
source: Adapted from Singapore Noodles, What To Cook Today, and Plum Village Restaurant.
description: A classic Hakka dish popular in Singapore, featuring whole chicken marinated with salt and aromatics, then wrapped and baked in hot salt. The result is incredibly juicy, tender, and fragrant meat, often served with ginger-scallion sauce.

name: Lor Kai Yik (Braised Chicken and Tofu Skewers)
source: Reconstructed from traditional Hakka/Teochew methods and Singaporean food history sources.
description: A nostalgic Hakka/Teochew dish once popular at Singapore street stalls, featuring chicken, tofu, and assorted ingredients braised in a rich, fermented red bean curd sauce. (Note: Authentic recipes are rare; this is a reconstructed version based on traditional methods.)

name: Ngoh Hiang (Five-Spice Meat Rolls)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Peranakan/Teochew home cooks.
description: A beloved Teochew/Peranakan dish in Singapore, featuring minced pork, prawn, and water chestnut seasoned with five spice, wrapped in beancurd skin and deep-fried. Served with sweet sauce and chili, it's a festive and hawker favorite.

name: Lu Rou Fan (Taiwanese Braised Pork Rice)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Chinese home cooks.
description: A beloved Taiwanese-Chinese dish popular in Singapore, featuring minced or diced pork belly braised in soy sauce, spices, and aromatics, served over steamed rice. Savory, rich, and comforting.

name: Braised Duck (Lor Ark)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Teochew/Chinese home cooks.
description: A classic Teochew/Chinese dish in Singapore, featuring whole duck braised in a savory, aromatic soy sauce with spices. Tender, flavorful, and often served with rice or yam rice.

name: Braised Pork Trotter (Lor Bak)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Chinese home cooks.
description: A classic Chinese comfort and festive dish in Singapore, featuring pork trotter braised in soy sauce, spices, and aromatics until tender and gelatinous. Served with rice or noodles.

name: Coffee Pork Ribs
source: https://www.noobcook.com/coffee-pork-ribs/
description: A zi char classic: pork ribs glazed in a sweet, sticky, aromatic coffee sauce. Tender, juicy, and deeply flavorful.

name: Ayam Penyet (Smashed Fried Chicken)
source: Adapted from Rasa Malaysia, The MeatMen, and Singapore Malay stalls.
description: A popular Indonesian-Singaporean dish: marinated chicken pieces deep-fried until crispy, then smashed and served with sambal, fried tofu, tempeh, and rice.

name: Oxtail Stew (Sup Buntut)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Eurasian/Malay kitchens.
description: A rich, hearty stew of oxtail simmered with potatoes, carrots, tomatoes, and spices. Popular in Eurasian, Malay, and Indonesian communities in Singapore.

name: Hakka Lei Cha (Thunder Tea Rice)
source: https://guide.michelin.com/sg/en/article/features/what-is-thunder-tea-rice, https://www.celestialpeach.com/blog/recipe-hakka-lei-cha-thunder-tea-vegan
description: A classic Hakka dish of steamed rice topped with a medley of finely chopped vegetables, tofu, peanuts, and pickles, served with a vibrant green herbal tea soup made from ground herbs, tea leaves, nuts, and seeds. Popular in Singapore's hawker centres for its health benefits and unique flavor.

name: Tahu Telur (Indonesian Beancurd Omelette)
source: Adapted from Rasa Malaysia, The MeatMen, and Singapore/Malay hawker stalls.
description: A popular Malay-Indonesian hawker dish in Singapore, featuring deep-fried tofu and egg tower, served with a sweet-spicy peanut sauce, cucumber, and bean sprouts. Crispy on the outside, soft inside, and bursting with flavor.

name: Vegetarian Fried Bee Hoon (Singapore Style)
source: Adapted from Veggie Temptation, Wikipedia, and local hawker practice.
description: A classic Singaporean vegetarian breakfast staple: stir-fried rice vermicelli with cabbage, mushrooms, tofu, carrots, and bean sprouts. Served at hawker centers and vegetarian stalls, often with curry gravy or sambal.

name: Vegetarian Lor Mee (Braised Noodles)
source: Adapted from Veggie Temptation, The MeatMen, and Singapore vegetarian stalls.
description: A vegetarian take on the Hokkien-Singaporean classic: thick yellow noodles in a rich, starchy braised gravy with mushrooms, tofu, and vegetables. Served with vinegar, garlic, and chili.

name: Thunder Tea Rice (Lei Cha Fan)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Veggie Temptation, and Singapore Hakka home kitchens.
description: A Hakka heritage dish popular at Singapore vegetarian stalls: rice topped with assorted vegetables, tofu, peanuts, and served with a fragrant green tea and herb soup.

name: Sayur Lodeh (Vegetable Coconut Curry)
source: Adapted from Rasa Malaysia, The MeatMen, and Singapore Malay kitchens.
description: A classic Malay/Peranakan vegetable curry: assorted vegetables simmered in a fragrant coconut milk broth with lemongrass, galangal, and spices. Served with rice or lontong (compressed rice cakes).

name: Lontong (Compressed Rice Cakes)
source: Adapted from Rasa Malaysia, The MeatMen, and Singapore Malay kitchens.
description: A staple accompaniment to sayur lodeh and festive Malay meals: rice cooked, compressed, and cut into firm cakes. Served with coconut curries, sambal, and serunding (spiced coconut).

name: Kedondong Salad (Ambarella Salad)
source: Adapted from Nyonya Cooking, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Peranakan kitchens.
description: A refreshing Peranakan and Malay salad of shredded kedondong (ambarella), carrots, cucumber, and peanuts, tossed in a tangy, spicy dressing. Popular at Nyonya and Malay tables.

name: Vadai (Indian-Style Savory Fritters)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian stalls.
description: A popular Indian-Singaporean snack: deep-fried savory fritters made from urad dal (black gram), spices, and curry leaves. Crispy outside, fluffy inside, often served with green chili or coconut chutney.

name: Chap Chye (Mixed Vegetable Stew)
source: Adapted from Nyonya Cooking, The MeatMen, and Singapore Peranakan kitchens.
description: A classic Peranakan and Chinese New Year dish: braised mixed vegetables with cabbage, mushrooms, bean curd sticks, glass noodles, and black fungus in a savory bean paste sauce.

name: Roti Kirai (Lacy Pancake)
source: Adapted from Rasa Malaysia, The MeatMen, and Singapore/Malay home cooks.
description: A festive Malay snack and side dish in Singapore, Roti Kirai are delicate, net-like pancakes made from a turmeric-flavored batter, traditionally served with chicken or beef curry. Popular at weddings and special occasions.

name: Braised Sea Cucumber with Mushrooms
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Chinese home cooks.
description: A luxurious Chinese banquet and festive dish in Singapore, featuring tender sea cucumber braised with shiitake mushrooms, dried scallops, and aromatics in a savory oyster sauce gravy. Served at celebrations and special occasions.

name: Century Egg Pork Porridge (Pi Dan Shou Rou Zhou)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Chinese home cooks.
description: A classic Chinese comfort food in Singapore, featuring silky rice porridge simmered with marinated pork and century egg, topped with spring onion, ginger, and fried shallots. Popular at hawker stalls and for breakfast.

name: Teochew Pumpkin Porridge (Teochew Nam Kua Zhou)
source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Teochew home cooks.
description: A classic Teochew/Chinese porridge in Singapore, featuring soft rice grains simmered with sweet pumpkin chunks. Served with simple side dishes, it's a comforting, home-style meal.

name: Kaya Toast
source: Adapted from Rasa Malaysia, The MeatMen, and Singapore kopitiams.
description: A beloved Singaporean breakfast: crisp toast spread with coconut jam (kaya) and butter, served with soft-boiled eggs and coffee. Iconic at kopitiams and breakfast stalls.
